DOC.HEAD: Concern for Reporters' Safety Clashes with Need To Get The Story
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Journalists itching to get to the hemisphere's story of the year have sometimes chafed at the restrictions imposed on them by the U.S. military. ``If we had it to do over again, we would never have allowed you all to come,'' said a harried Air Force Col. Ronald Sconyers, spokesman for the U.S. Southern Command. Reporting has indeed been dangerous _ though not impossible _ in the days following the U.S. invasion that began Wednesday. Snipers, Panamanian Defense Force resisters, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's Dignity Battalion fighters, looters, and various and sundry assailants roamed the city with U.S. soldiers searching for Noriega himself. Several reporters, including Candice Hughes of The Associated Press, were held hostage and threatened with death by Noriega loyalists before they were set free. The U.S. Embassy said Saturday that pro-Noriega forces had released Jon Meyersohn, a CBS producer seized Wednesday at the Marriott Hotel, and American businessman Doug Mullen. CBS said Mullen was an executive with GTE and was taken hostage with Meyersohn. Some journalists were not so lucky. A Spanish photographer was killed and two foreign journalists were wounded by gunfire. Before dawn Friday, about 300 journalists arrived here. But the Southern Command kept most of them cooped up at Howard Air Base and on nearby Rodman Naval Station. Clad in a helmet and full battle gear, Sconyers briefed a hungry, tired, unwashed legion of reporters late Friday at Howard, four miles west of Panama City. ``A reporter's job is currently impossible on the streets of Panama City,'' he said. The journalists slept on the floor and lived on hot dogs and popcorn while waiting for permission to leave. Though mindful of the danger in Panama City, most of the journalists began to chafe at the restrictions. By Saturday morning, Southern Command authorities had convinced about a third of the journalists to return home. The command then ``released'' the other reporters. ``I can understand why they did it. I don't like it, but I understand it,'' said one U.S. reporter. A handful of journalists was able to get into Panama on small chartered planes Thursday before two big charters _ one from Miami and the other from neighboring Costa Rica _ arrived early Friday. It was that descent of hundreds of reporters that set off alarms at the Southern Command. One reporter who arrived Thursday, Marjorie Miller of the Los Angeles Times, said it was dangerous to report from the streets Friday and that setting loose several hundred reporters _ most with little or no experience in Panama or in combat _ could have had grave consequences. ``There were a lot of people with guns on the streets,'' said Ms. Miller, who has worked in Central America for several years covering war and social upheaval. One reporter called the restrictions an attempt to ``breast-feed'' the media with what the Southern Command wanted reporters to hear and to keep them away from the ugly side of the invasion. He said individual reporters and their organizations should be allowed to consider the risks and take responsibility for their coverage.
